bibl.note: This document is a letter written by Cherokee Colonel Gideon Morgan to Colonel Return J. Meigs on February 4, 1814. The letter is Morgan's account of a battle during the Creek War of 1813-1814, in which General Andrew Jackson's American forces allied with the Cherokee against Creek warriors. While it first appeared that the Creeks had the upper-hand in the battle, Jackson's troops were able to maintain their ground and gain victory in the end. Morgan was able to estimate the losses on both sides, and he stated that afterwards the Cherokee were permitted to return to their homes. Morgan, who was writing from Fort Armstrong, also reported that more troops and Cherokees were expected to arrive at the fort, and he noted that at that time provisions were scarce.

div1.opener:
Fort armstrong
Febry 4th 1814
Colo. R. J. Meigs
Sir:
div1.p:
a number of Cherokees having assembled at this place who appeard determined on an emertion into the Creek nation to form a Junction with
Genl Jackson in his Late tour on the talapoosy
I viwd the enterprise highly impropper as being too weak to act by ourselves and Jacksons situation was but imperfectly known to us inded I had but Little hopes of Joining him as I then thought his object might be different from the prevailing opinion which I thought had obtained Circulation. the better to Secure his Real object. My intreaties were without effect nothing Could Remove their Stubborn determination when I agreed to accompany them we Left this on the 23rd Janry and directed our Course for the Hillabees but on our arrival at the fork of the path which Leads to the Hillabees and Chinabees fort of friendly Creeks on the Choctaw Coches they Changed their Rout to fall in the Rear of
Genl Jackson on our arrival at the fort we found from the Relation of the Creeks that Jackson had on the 22nd two ingagements with the hostile party in which a number of woonded was throne uppon his hands which Compeld him to Retrogade on the 24 the indians having Reenforced in Considerable numbers made a Vigorous attack on his Rear who in a cowardly manner Retreated and Left the company of artilery to maintain the unqiet Content. they However maintained their Ground and eventually
put the enemy to Rout. they have proven what a few determined diciplined men can perform they have cloathed themselves with immortal honours. finding
Genl. Jackson unable with Safety to maintain his situation I had no difficulty in inducing them to follow the army to the to Islands which we Reachd the same day with Jacksonin there Several ingagements the enemy have Lost 200 of them but wariors we have to Lament the Loss of some brave men 20 fell on the field and 5 have since died of their woonds. and 55 additional woonded many badly but none dangerous.

The Cherokees were permitted to Return to their Respective homes on the tattered lands to Rendesvous at this place on the 20th at which time it is hoped they will Generally attend active operations will Commence about the 25th at which time it is Supposed the whole army will moove. be pleased to urge
Capt Taylor to attend his Services I found on our former movements of some importance. I shall indeavour to Call at Highawassee before Long when I will more fully detail to you our moovement.

Mayor Walker is here and intends Continuing with about 100 wariors
the Ridge. Threeboats and the indians from that Quarter are daily expected. I have Requested him to delay his Junction to the 20th
Lowry Brown and their men who were about marching have been advised to delay also. provisions are Scearce and no prospect of an immediate Supply. Should
they arive they must depend on their Guns for Subsistance

closer.salute:
accept assureances of My
perfect Esteem
